title: Kevin Federline is asking Britney Spears to pay him $60,000 a month in child support — and people are telling him to 'get a real job'
text:
Kevin Federline wants Britney Spears to triple his child support payment. Getty Images

Britney Spears' ex-husband Kevin Federline wants her to pay him more child support— raising her payments from $20,000 a month to $60,000, according to The Blast.

In court documents, Federline said he makes $3,000 a month as a DJ and can't work as a dancer anymore because of his age.

K-Fed also noted that he's less "in demand" and has "not been as successful in putting out new music" as he was 10 years ago.

People dragged the 40-year-old DJ on Twitter, with many saying he doesn't need that much money to care for their children and that he should get a "real job."

Kevin Federline says he should no longer have to live on a mere $20,000 a month.

The 40-year-old DJ, who shares two children with ex-wife Britney Spears, filed court documents requesting she raise his payments from the current $20,000 a month to $60,000, according to The Blast.

"My income has changed significantly since the child support was last modified in approximately 2008 because I no longer earn a six-figure income like I did in 2008," Federline said in the documents. "I am no longer able to perform as a dancer due to my age, and I have not been as successful in putting out new music as I was in 2008. I am simply less of a 'name' and less in demand than I was in 2008, which has negatively affected my income."

Federline said he deserves more because he's "less of a name" than he was in 2008. Getty Images

Federline, who has four other children with two other women, according to Yahoo, said in court documents that he makes $3,000 a month as a DJ.

Spears, as her ex pointed out in the documents, is "one of the most recognized musical performers of our time." The singer is worth an estimated $215 million, according to Celebrity Net Worth.

The couple, who was married from 2004 to 2007, have two sons together, 12-year-old Sean and 11-year-old Jayden James Federline, according to Yahoo Lifestyle.

Federline was awarded full custody of the two boys in 2008 after Spears was hospitalized for a psychiatric evaluation, according to TMZ.

For the past 10 years, Spears has been under a court-ordered conservatorship that means she cannot make certain personal or financial decisions without the approval of her father and her lawyer, and that she cannot have full custody of her children, according to US magazine. Her father is looking into ending the conservatorship, the magazine reported.

Britney Spears with her niece, Lexi, and her sons, Sean and Jayden James, at the Teen Choice Awards in 2015 AP Images

Federline said there is "an extreme disparity between the lifestyle enjoyed by the parties' minor children in [Spears'] home and in [Federline's] home," according to The Blast.

"[Spears] is a single woman who lives alone in a 13,264 square foot Neoclassical Italianate [sp] villa on 21 acres of land in a gated community with an elevator, a library, a media/game room, 3,500 bottle wine cellar, an additional 1,200 square foot pool house, an orchard, resort-sized pool and spa, lighted tennis court and three-green golf course," Federline wrote in the court documents. "In contrast, [Federline] lives with his wife, his two minor children from his current marriage, the two minor children he shares with [Spears] and two minor children from a previous relationship in a 2,000 square foot home."

Spears has earned $100 million from her Las Vegas concert residency, according to Forbes. Getty Images

The document points out that Spears has private chefs, tutors, and other household staff available for her children, as well as "toys" including ATVs, video game systems, iPads, and laptops.

Federline also alleged that while Spears takes their children on multiple vacations a year at luxury resorts, he cannot afford to take them on vacation.

He also claimed that he doesn't have space at his home to host 15 of their children's friends over for a sleepover.

Federline and his wife, Victoria Prince, at an event in 2009 Getty Images

Bernard Post, a New York-based divorce attorney, told Yahoo that "it's not unreasonable to argue that each parent should provide a comparable lifestyle, but it's not necessary to replicate that lifestyle verbatim."

He said the real question is how Federline uses the $20,000 he currently gets from Spears each month.

"It boggles the mind that he would ask for more money," Post told Yahoo.

He's apparently not the only one who thinks so.

People on Twitter slammed K-Fed's request, saying that the current payments should be more than enough and that Spears shouldn't have to fund his "fancy lifestyle."

Many echoed the sentiment that Federline should get a "real job."

Others said that Spears worked hard for her money and deserves to have whatever lifestyle she wants.

This Twitter user's simple message, however, may have said it best.

Enough said.
